comments.text:
Also the Ancient Greeks were Mediterranean people. They were just as dark, 
if not darker, than the Persians they were fighting. They would never have 
called themselves "white" if they were still around, and nor would you. The 
spartans in 300 are all British actors lol ﻿
comments.author: Chipp aH

comments.text:
It depends on where in the country you are.

In central/northern Spain, italy and Greece, the averge skin colour is a 
creamy white (tanned, though, by the sun), and it is rather common to see 
people who have naturally light brown or blonde hair with naturally green, 
light brown, hazel or blue eyes alongside the darker eye and hair colours.

In Spain, only really the very south around Grenada/Andalusia has any 
noticeable Arab blood. Most Spainards and Portuguese are a creamy, 'dark' 
white colour (not pale like Northern Europeans), tanned by the sun.

The same with most Italians and Greeks.

Also, in relation to the ancient Greeks, you have to remember these events 
happened thousands of years ago and from the works we have, the Greeks do 
actually call themselves white (not directly, just when they are describing 
either themselves or other Greeks). Same with the Romans (and 
Roman-described Iberians).

It is very possible that Ancient Greeks were light skinned, just tanned due 
to the sun.
comments.author: titytit

a Celt or a German either.﻿
